dataset.title: Alaskan Peatland Experiment: Community structure and productivity data for 2007-2010 IX - Stem Density

address.deliveryPoint: Biology and Wildlife Irving I; North Koyukuk Dr.
Department of Integrative Biology University of Guelph
Alaska Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit University of Alaska Fairbanks Irving I Building
Boreal Ecology Cooperative Research Unit, PNW Research Station, USDA Forest Service, P.O. Box 756780,University of Alaska Fairbanks

abstract.para: This dataset contains stem density counts for each species within sub-collar plots (5 per collar) with the gas flux collars at each plot and site of the Alaskan Peatland Experiment. Stem counts were started at the fen in 2008, while counts started at the bog in 2009. Within the fen site a water table manipulation has been ongiong since 2005, with control, lowered and raised water table treatment plots. Samples at the bog were collected in a plot established within the lowland black spruce permafrost plateau (permafrost), and two plots established within collapse scars embedded within the plateau. One collapse scar formed ~ 45 years ago (old collapse) and the other formed ~ 25 years ago based upon aerial photography provided by the BCEF LTER. The data provided in this data set can be sorted by site and plot.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: The bog site contains 3 plots, one in an area of stable permafrost (Permafrost plot), one in a thermokarst collapse scar ~45 years old and another collapse scar ~ 25 years old. At the fen site there are three water table manipulation plots ( control, lowered, and raised) with 3 open top chambers nested within each plot (data from OTCs was not collected, unless otherwise noted).

section.title: Methods
section.para: FIELD: Stem density for each dominant species per m2 within a plot was measured periodically during the growing season (every two weeks in 2010). Stem density estimates were calculated for five replicate samples (sub-collar plots) (7.5 cm x 7.5 cm) within gas flux collars within each plot.There were 3 collars subplots in each water table treatment at the fen. In 2009 I established 12, 6, and 6 collars at the new collapse, old collapse and permafrost plots respectively. In 2010, I used 9, 6, and 6 collars in the new collapse, old collapse and permafrost plots, respectively.

section.title: Sampling Frequency
section.para: Measurements of stem density were collected only at the fen in 2008 approximately monthly, and at both bog and fen in 2009, although only twice. In the summer of 2010 stem density was measured every two weeks at both the fen and bog.
